pregnancy_tips.title: ðŸ”¶ Pregnancy Tips
items: Make sure to eat a healthy, balanced diet rich in vitamins and minerals
Regularly follow up your pregnancy with your doctor every month or as advised
Avoid medicines and treatments without consulting your doctor
Take recommended vitamins such as folic acid and iron
Engage in light exercises like walking or prenatal yoga
Stay away from stress and create a calm and comfortable environment
Monitor any serious symptoms like bleeding, persistent pain, or weak fetal movements
Do regular checks for sugar and blood pressure as per doctor's instructions

birth_preparation.title: ðŸ”¶ Birth Preparation
items: Prepare your hospital bag from the eighth month (clothes, diapers, papers, your necessities)
Learn about labor signs: regular contractions, water breaking, lower back pain
Discuss with your doctor about your birth plan (natural or cesarean)
Prepare someone to accompany you during labor (husband or mother)
Learn breathing exercises helpful during labor

postpartum_psychological_tips.title: ðŸ”¶ Psychological Tips for the Mother After Birth
items: Watch for symptoms of postpartum depression (persistent sadness, crying, extreme fatigue)
Ask for support from your spouse and family, and don't hesitate to seek psychological help
Try to rest when the baby sleeps to regain your energy
Eat well, drink plenty of fluids, and take care of yourself as you take care of the baby
Talk with other mothers; sharing experiences helps a lot

postpartum_depression_treatment.title: ðŸ”¶ Postpartum Depression Treatment and Psychological Support
items: Consult a psychiatrist or mental health specialist if you feel persistent sadness or depression symptoms
Share your feelings with your spouse, close friends, or family members
Ensure good sleep and enough rest even if the baby is disruptive at first
Practice breathing exercises, relaxation, or light yoga
Avoid isolation and try to get regular fresh air
Eat a healthy diet and avoid caffeine and stimulants
If symptoms persist for a long time, the doctor may prescribe medications safe during breastfeeding
Join support groups for mothers to share experiences and get psychological help

postpartum_nutrition.title: ðŸ”¶ Healthy Nutrition for the Breastfeeding Mother
items: Drink plenty of water throughout the day to maintain milk production
Eat balanced meals containing protein, calcium, and vitamins
Avoid caffeine, alcohol, and stimulants
Increase intake of fresh vegetables and fruits
Ensure good rest and sleep to improve milk quality
Consult your doctor or nutritionist if you have digestive problems or allergies

breastfeeding_problems.title: ðŸ”¶ Breastfeeding Problems and How to Deal With Them
items: Nipple pain: use natural creams and keep the breast clean
Low milk supply: try breast pumps or increase breastfeeding frequency
Blocked milk ducts: focus on gentle breast massage
Breast infections: consult a doctor immediately if redness or heat appears
Follow a healthy diet to support milk production

babycare.title: ðŸ”¶ Newborn Care
items: Exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months is very important for the baby's growth
Change diapers regularly to avoid rashes
Clean the baby's umbilical cord gently, and keep the body clean daily
Monitor the baby's temperature and watch for any changes in behavior
Do not let the baby sleep on their stomach to avoid the risk of suffocation
Create a safe sleeping environment: firm mattress, no many toys around

baby_vaccinations.title: ðŸ”¶ Child Vaccinations by Age
items: At birth: Hepatitis B vaccine (within the first 24 hours)
At 2 months: 5 essential vaccines (DTP, Hib, Polio, Hep B, Pneumococcal)
At 4 months: repeat the previous vaccines
At 6 months: additional doses plus seasonal flu vaccine
At 9 months: first measles vaccine
At 12 months: MMR, chickenpox, hepatitis A vaccines
Keep vaccination card and update it regularly with your doctor

baby_growth_monthly.title: ðŸ”¶ Baby Growth Month by Month
items: 1 month: starts to lift head slightly, recognizes mother's voice
2 months: smiles, follows moving objects with eyes
3-4 months: starts to grasp toys, makes happy sounds
5-6 months: sits with support, rolls from tummy to back and vice versa
7-9 months: starts crawling, says simple words like mama and papa
10-12 months: stands with help, takes steps, imitates movements

baby_feeding_after_6_months.title: ðŸ”¶ Feeding Baby After 6 Months
items: Start introducing solid foods after 6 months while continuing breastfeeding
Begin with mashed vegetables like zucchini, potatoes, carrots
Introduce a new food every 3 days to monitor for allergies
Avoid honey, salt, and sugar during the first year
Continue breastfeeding or formula feeding with solid food
Offer food with a texture suitable for the baby's age and mouth development
Watch stool and skin for any signs of allergy or intolerance

home_safety_for_baby.title: ðŸ”¶ Home Safety to Protect Your Baby
items: Install barriers on stairs and windows
Keep medicines and cleaning products out of baby's reach
Secure heavy furniture to the wall to prevent tipping
Cover electrical outlets with safety plugs
Do not leave baby alone on bed or table
Use high chairs with safety belts during meals
Always supervise the baby during playtime or crawling

common_childhood_illnesses.title: ðŸ”¶ Dealing with Common Childhood Illnesses
items: Cold: rest the baby, give warm fluids, consult a doctor if cough persists
Infant colic: soothe the baby, change positions, gently massage the belly
Rash: avoid tight clothing, use natural moisturizers, consult doctor if needed
Fever: monitor temperature, use appropriate fever reducers, see doctor if very high
Diarrhea: keep fluids up, avoid heavy foods, consult doctor if it continues

father_role_postpartum.title: ðŸ”¶ Father's Role in Supporting Mother and Caring for Baby
items: Help the mother care for the baby like changing diapers and giving formula feeding if needed
Provide psychological and moral support, listen to her
Assist with house chores to ease her burden
Attend doctor visits with the mother for checkups
Be patient and flexible with the mother's mood swings
Learn baby care basics and participate in all growth stages
